Award.AwardTitle: Quantifying the 18O/16O of Glacial Meltwater Pulses Using a Novel LA-ICPMS/IRMS Multiproxy Approach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The growth and decay of large ice sheets over the North American continent during the last glacial period had far reaching effects on climate and ocean circulation. Meltwater input into the oceans during deglaciation caused sea level to rise and has been invoked as a cause for rapid climate change. However, the relative volumetric contributions of individual meltwater pulses has been difficult to constrain, and often relies on assumptions about the stable isotope composition of the North American (Laurentide) ice sheet meltwater geochemistry. The fact that the ice sheets themselves had heterogeneous compositions, varying in both time and space, makes reconstruction a challenge.

This research, carried out by scientists at the University of California at Davis, develops a novel technique to determine the instantaneous oxygen isotope composition of meltwater from the North American ice sheet. Measurements of both trace element (Mg/Ca and Ba/Ca) and oxygen isotope (δ18O) composition will be made on individual shells of planktonic foraminifera preserved in sediments of the Gulf of Mexico. Specific goals of the project are to: 1) refine the sample preparation and measurement protocols, 2) improve the calibration of the Ba/Ca salinity proxy, 3) test the technique by computing modern Mississippi River water using the new method, and 4) compute the oxygen isotope composition or river/meltwater during selected intervals of the deglaciation (Termination I) and Marine Isotope Stage 3.

In terms of broader impacts, funding supports a female doctoral candidate and offers the opportunity for undergraduates to be exposed to state of the art analytical methods. The methods developed in the course of this work method could potentially be widely applied in paleoceanographic studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
At the end of the last Ice Age, 18,000 years ago, much of North America was covered by an ice sheet more than one mile-high that extended from the Atlantic to the Pacific Oceans. The melting and catastrophic collapse of this ice sheet over the subsequent 8,000 years provides a direct analog for the melting behavior of modern ice sheets on Greenland and Antarctica. In the research funded by this grant, we focused on the history of the collapse of the North American Laurentide Ice Sheet, as recorded in layers of sediment on the ocean floor of the Gulf of Mexico. As ice melted, the meltwater traveled down the Mississippi River into the Gulf of Mexico. Although the mouth of the Mississippi was >1,000 miles from the edge of the ice sheet in some places, the water coming from the ice had a distinctly different microchemistry than that of ocean water. This chemical difference altered Gulf of Mexico seawater chemistry, and the chemical change was recorded in the shells of a group of plankton organisms called foraminifera that lived in the surface waters south of the Mississippi River outflow during that time. When the foraminifera died, their shells sank to the ocean bottom, leaving a record of the history of ice sheet demise in ocean sediments.

In our research, we applied an emergent technology called laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICPMS) to develop a brand new approach to calculating the chemistry of the meltwater draining off the ice sheet. We targeted the shells of plankton that grew in the surface ocean during meltwater events and analyzed individual plankton shells combining multiple techniques including LA-ICPMS and traditional isotope analyses of oxygen to reconstruct micron scale shell geochemistry. Our technique used the novel approach of not only combining multiple measurements on single foraminifera shells, but examining populations of multiple plankton shells that coexisted during a single meltwater event. In this way, we were able to apply concepts from modern plankton ecology to unravel the timing and nature of ice sheet meltwater chemical variation in the ocean.

With this technique, we were able to compute the oxygen isotope chemistry of ice sheet meltwater change with decade resolution. These chemical changes give us information on the source of the ice with respect to ice sheet elevation and/or relative latitude of the ice on North America. After analyzing many sedimentary intervals between 16,000 and 12,000 years ago, we compiled a long-term picture of how the North American ice sheet collapsed over a period of 4,000 years. Our data revealed the pattern of North American ice sheet demise during its collapse, and provides a unique perspective related to the pattern and mechanism of ice sheet melting during a warming climate.
